content.raw:
I just introduced a major restructuring of the implementation to make the concept work for plugins.

I've also added an integration test that uses a mock plugin that provides a mock feature. The test can be found in `test/integration/FeatureSystem.cc`, and the mock plugin implementation can be found in `test/plugins/mock.cc`.

Right now the test only has the plugin implementing one feature, so I think the next step should be to add (at least) one more feature to it. Next week, I might have to shift gears towards SOSS work, since we have some hard deadlines coming up, but I may be able to add to the test this weekend.

content.raw:
I've removed the WIP tag because I'm satisfied with the implementation and tests (of course there could always be more testing, but I believe the critical concepts of the Feature System are being adequately tested now).

There are still two caveats for this PR:

1. One of the tests is using `Eigen` to show how a single "feature" can be used to construct an API for both 2D and 3D simulations (see `test/MockCenterOfMass`). `Eigen` is useful for this because the `Eigen` data structures can be templated on the dimensionality of the matrix/vector. This means that the tests currently depend on `Eigen`, and we need to use the current `default` branch of `ign-cmake`.

2. We need to use the `BetterPluginRegistration_DllManagement` branch of `ign-common`, because that's where proper support for template interfaces is introduced. I'll look into getting the `ign-plugin` repo into serviceable shape to be used by `ign-physics`, but my time available for ignition work this week might be somewhat limited.
content.html:
I've removed the WIP tag because I'm satisfied with the implementation and tests (of course there could always be more testing, but I believe the critical concepts of the Feature System are being adequately tested now).

There are still two caveats for this PR:

  1. One of the tests is using Eigen to show how a single "feature" can be used to construct an API for both 2D and 3D simulations (see test/MockCenterOfMass). Eigen is useful for this because the Eigen data structures can be templated on the dimensionality of the matrix/vector. This means that the tests currently depend on Eigen, and we need to use the current default branch of ign-cmake.

  2. We need to use the BetterPluginRegistration_DllManagement branch of ign-common, because that's where proper support for template interfaces is introduced. I'll look into getting the ign-plugin repo into serviceable shape to be used by ign-physics, but my time available for ignition work this week might be somewhat limited.

content.raw:
> I'm seeing lots of template parameters `typename Policy`, and I'm not sure what that means.

Your followup is correct: this refers to policy-based design. We might be able to come up with a better name for this template parameter than `Policy`, but I haven’t thought of a better name yet.

Currently, we use the `Policy` parameter class to tell the template whether it should be a 2D object or a 3D object, as well as whether it should use `double` or `float` precision. In the future, we could devise more policy properties which could affect the structure or behavior of features, but I haven't thought of any other potential properties yet. It's also possible for custom plugins to define their own policy properties and embed those into the `Policy` class.

> if you're just looking at the `Entity` class, it's hard to know what the `Policy` means.

Yeah, this is one of the biggest disadvantages of CRTP design \(second only to the craziness of C\+\+ template syntax\). Since the template implementations are recursive, it’s hard to start at one point and work your way up/down when trying to understand the code. Most likely, you’ll need to cycle through the code several times before fully grokking it.

The upside is, it’s an extremely powerful pattern which is highly maintainable because of the way concerns are separated. It’s just the initial attempt to understand it that requires a lot of legwork. Luckily, only maintainers need to do that legwork; users shouldn’t have to worry about those details.
content.html:

Currently, we use the Policy parameter class to tell the template whether it should be a 2D object or a 3D object, as well as whether it should use double or float precision. In the future, we could devise more policy properties which could affect the structure or behavior of features, but I haven't thought of any other potential properties yet. It's also possible for custom plugins to define their own policy properties and embed those into the Policy class.

if you're just looking at the Entity class, it's hard to know what the Policy means.

Yeah, this is one of the biggest disadvantages of CRTP design (second only to the craziness of C++ template syntax). Since the template implementations are recursive, it’s hard to start at one point and work your way up/down when trying to understand the code. Most likely, you’ll need to cycle through the code several times before fully grokking it.

The upside is, it’s an extremely powerful pattern which is highly maintainable because of the way concerns are separated. It’s just the initial attempt to understand it that requires a lot of legwork. Luckily, only maintainers need to do that legwork; users shouldn’t have to worry about those details.

content.raw:
The implementation of the Feature System is essentially a mix of ECS, PIMPL, and Variadic CRTP patterns.

The `Identity` of an `Entity` is a crucial piece of the ECS aspect of the design. Every object must correctly know its `Identity` or else we can easily experience undefined behavior or segmentation faults.

I've put in a bunch of constraints to try to ensure that an `Entity` will never be given a bogus `Identity`. Specifically, I've made it so that only physics plugins themselves are able to produce `Identity` objects.

Nevertheless, implementation mistakes could be made, either within the feature system implementation or within a plugin implementation. To make those kinds of mistakes a little more obvious, the default construction of `Entity` and `Identity` will produce an `Identity::id` with a value of `INVALID_ENTITY_ID`, a.k.a. `std::numeric_limits<std::size_t>::max()`. If an `Identity` object ever has that value, we can immediately know that something went wrong during its construction, and if a user ever holds an `Entity` with an invalid `Identity`, then it most likely means that our implementation has a bug \(or the user is intentionally doing something that they’re not supposed to\).
content.html:
The implementation of the Feature System is essentially a mix of ECS, PIMPL, and Variadic CRTP patterns.

The Identity of an Entity is a crucial piece of the ECS aspect of the design. Every object must correctly know its Identity or else we can easily experience undefined behavior or segmentation faults.

I've put in a bunch of constraints to try to ensure that an Entity will never be given a bogus Identity. Specifically, I've made it so that only physics plugins themselves are able to produce Identity objects.

Nevertheless, implementation mistakes could be made, either within the feature system implementation or within a plugin implementation. To make those kinds of mistakes a little more obvious, the default construction of Entity and Identity will produce an Identity::id with a value of INVALID_ENTITY_ID, a.k.a. std::numeric_limits<std::size_t>::max(). If an Identity object ever has that value, we can immediately know that something went wrong during its construction, and if a user ever holds an Entity with an invalid Identity, then it most likely means that our implementation has a bug (or the user is intentionally doing something that they’re not supposed to).

content.raw:
Good catch! This is an outdated implementation from before the `Identity` class existed. Because of the weirdness of templates, this code won’t get compiled until the function gets used; that’s the only reason the compiler allowed it.

In [4d7d2e7](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/commits/4d7d2e7e19836ca748d97553a55f338664174d36?at=default) it’s been updated, and I added a test for each function. By having a test use each function, the functions get compiled, and we’ll see any compilation errors that might be in them.
content.html:
Good catch! This is an outdated implementation from before the Identity class existed. Because of the weirdness of templates, this code won’t get compiled until the function gets used; that’s the only reason the compiler allowed it.

In 4d7d2e7 it’s been updated, and I added a test for each function. By having a test use each function, the functions get compiled, and we’ll see any compilation errors that might be in them.

content.raw: Does it matter if a FeatureList has duplicate features?
content.html: Does it matter if a FeatureList has duplicate features?

Duplicate features are never supposed to be an issue.

There is one known pathological case right now, though: In rare cases, if a feature is side-by-side with itself in a FeatureList, then this will sometimes trigger a compilation error which originates from ignition::common::SpecializedPluginPtr. It turns out that C++ doesn’t like you double-inheriting at the same level in a class hierarchy. In other words:

class Child : public virtual Parent, public virtual Parent
{
};

will produce a compilation error, even though there's nothing inherently wrong with it conceptually. Once in a while, we'll get this compilation error from SpecializedPluginPtr when features are arranged just right in a FeatureList.

I have plans to fix this in the upcoming ignition::plugin::SpecializedPluginPtr. We can't do anything about it from ign-physics.

content.raw: I see. So I see two static_asserts; one in `FeatureList` that confirms `!SelfConflict`, but it helps to have this embedded static_assert as well so we can see which Feature is the problem. I think I get it
content.html: I see. So I see two static_asserts; one in FeatureList that confirms !SelfConflict, but it helps to have this embedded static_assert as well so we can see which Feature is the problem. I think I get it

content.raw: That's exactly right. Technically speaking, the `static_assert` in `FeaureList` will never get triggered, because if there is ever a conflict, then the compiler will exit at the embedded `static_assert`. But we need that outer `static_assert` to be in the `FeatureList` class template definition to make sure that the embedded `static_assert` is reached by the compiler for every instantiation of a `FeatureList`.
content.html: That's exactly right. Technically speaking, the static_assert in FeaureList will never get triggered, because if there is ever a conflict, then the compiler will exit at the embedded static_assert. But we need that outer static_assert to be in the FeatureList class template definition to make sure that the embedded static_assert is reached by the compiler for every instantiation of a FeatureList.

~~~
diff -r 0b4ccbbf71e9 include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh
--- a/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh	Tue Jun 26 14:21:51 2018 +0800
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh	Thu Jun 28 17:43:03 2018 -0700

       struct TupleContainsBase<T, std::tuple<Types...>>
           : std::integral_constant<bool,

+              std::is_same<

-                  std::is_base_of<T, Types>::value, Empty, Types>::type...>,

~~~

--- a/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh    Tue Jun 26 14:21:51 2018 +0800
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh    Thu Jun 28 17:43:03 2018 -0700
@@ -163,9 +163,9 @@
       template <typename T, typename... Types>
       struct TupleContainsBase<T, std::tuple<Types...>>
           : std::integral_constant<bool,
-              !std::is_same<
+              std::is_same<
                 std::tuple<typename std::conditional<
-                  std::is_base_of<T, Types>::value, Empty, Types>::type...>,

                 std::tuple<Types...>
               >::value> { };

no response needed really, but the logic is just tricky for me to follow

content.raw:
I’ll go ahead and break it down for anyone else who might have found this confusing.

This patch changes the logic from “at least one member of the tuple matches `T`" to "every member of the tuple matches `T`”.

The parameter pack expansion \(which is done by `...`\) will effectively go through each type in the parameter pack `Types` and check whether it matches `T`. If one of the members of the parameter pack matches `T`, then that member will be replaced by the `Empty` class when constructing the test tuple. Then the test tuple will be compared against the original tuple. If any member in the test tuple has been modified, then `std::is_same<TestTuple, OriginalTuple>` will return false, which tells us that we found at least one match for `T` in the original tuple.

Removing the `!` changes the logic from “at least one member of the tuple matches `T`” to “every member of the tuple is different than `T`". Then swapping `Types` and `Empty` changes the logic from "every member of the tuple is different than `T`" to "every member of the tuple matches `T`". The two changes don't quite cancel each other out, because each one is negating a different scope of the logic. It's kind of like how `!(A && B)` becomes `!A || !B`.
content.html:
I’ll go ahead and break it down for anyone else who might have found this confusing.

This patch changes the logic from “at least one member of the tuple matches T" to "every member of the tuple matches T”.

The parameter pack expansion (which is done by ...) will effectively go through each type in the parameter pack Types and check whether it matches T. If one of the members of the parameter pack matches T, then that member will be replaced by the Empty class when constructing the test tuple. Then the test tuple will be compared against the original tuple. If any member in the test tuple has been modified, then std::is_same<TestTuple, OriginalTuple> will return false, which tells us that we found at least one match for T in the original tuple.

Removing the ! changes the logic from “at least one member of the tuple matches T” to “every member of the tuple is different than T". Then swapping Types and Empty changes the logic from "every member of the tuple is different than T" to "every member of the tuple matches T". The two changes don't quite cancel each other out, because each one is negating a different scope of the logic. It's kind of like how !(A && B) becomes !A || !B.

content.raw:
I definitely agree that a name change is needed with that file and/or plugin.

When I first wrote the mock plugin, I wasn’t sure how big it would become in future PRs as we add more features to test. When it came time to write the Frame Semantics test, I decided it would be better to have separate plugin libraries for each plugin concept that we’re trying to test, so I created a separate plugin specifically for testing Frame Semantics.

Since this plugin is mostly about testing the retrieval of Entities, what if we call it something like `test/plugins/MockEntities.cc` and then the plugin itself can be renamed to something like `mock::EntitiesPlugin`?

content.raw:
why is this a `unique_ptr`?

also, I'm still reading this, so I may figure out why shortly, but I wonder why this function is not `const`
content.html:
why is this a unique_ptr?

also, I'm still reading this, so I may figure out why shortly, but I wonder why this function is not const

content.raw:
It's a `std::unique_ptr` so that we're able to return a `nullptr` if a world with the requested name doesn't exist. I would prefer using `std::optional`, but I haven’t upgraded my machine to Bionic yet, so I don’t have C\+\+17 compatibility.

I'd suggest we switch this to `std::optional` once we’re ready to \(force me to\) move to Bionic.
content.html:
It's a std::unique_ptr so that we're able to return a nullptr if a world with the requested name doesn't exist. I would prefer using std::optional, but I haven’t upgraded my machine to Bionic yet, so I don’t have C++17 compatibility.

I'd suggest we switch this to std::optional once we’re ready to (force me to) move to Bionic.

content.raw: `std::optional` sounds fine. I guess my main question is why `unique_ptr` instead of a raw pointer? The reason I asked is because `unique_ptr` makes me think about ownership and life-cycle.
content.html: std::optional sounds fine. I guess my main question is why unique_ptr instead of a raw pointer? The reason I asked is because unique_ptr makes me think about ownership and life-cycle.

content.raw:
The object that we’re returning is a proxy for *something* that exists in the physics engine. The physics engine doesn’t have any knowledge or ownership over the life-cycle of this proxy object that we’re returning; only the user is able to see it.

To take this particular line as an example, the physics engine might not have any concept of a “World” object, and even if it did, we can’t give the user a pointer to the physics engine’s native “World” object, because the API\+ABI of “World” objects will differ between physics engines. At compile time, we have no way of knowing what physics engine will be used.

So the object we're handing to the user is a proxy "Entity" that refers to the physics engine's "World" using a unique integer value. The life-cycle of this proxy "Entity" needs to be managed, but only the user knows about the existence of this proxy object. Therefore, the user needs to be responsible for its life-cycle, but we take care of that by wrapping it in a `std::unique_ptr`.

If we were able to **know** that a valid "World" can be returned for every possible input that the user provides, then we could return a regular `World` proxy object instead of a `std::unique_ptr<World>` object. Alternatively, we could always return a `World` object, and throw an exception when the user gives bad input \(instead of returning a `nullptr`\), but the fact that a function might throw an exception can’t be expressed through its function signature, so I don’t favor that option \(plus there are some potential performance concerns\).

`std::optional<World>` is really be the best fit here \(at least in my opinion\), because it will give us the best of:

1. Explicitly expressing intent \+ behavior
2. Good performance
3. Meaningful life-cycle management

I just don’t have C\+\+17 right now, and I can’t risk upgrading to Bionic until July 16, because I have a live demo scheduled for the 13th.
content.html:
The object that we’re returning is a proxy for something that exists in the physics engine. The physics engine doesn’t have any knowledge or ownership over the life-cycle of this proxy object that we’re returning; only the user is able to see it.

To take this particular line as an example, the physics engine might not have any concept of a “World” object, and even if it did, we can’t give the user a pointer to the physics engine’s native “World” object, because the API+ABI of “World” objects will differ between physics engines. At compile time, we have no way of knowing what physics engine will be used.

So the object we're handing to the user is a proxy "Entity" that refers to the physics engine's "World" using a unique integer value. The life-cycle of this proxy "Entity" needs to be managed, but only the user knows about the existence of this proxy object. Therefore, the user needs to be responsible for its life-cycle, but we take care of that by wrapping it in a std::unique_ptr.

If we were able to know that a valid "World" can be returned for every possible input that the user provides, then we could return a regular World proxy object instead of a std::unique_ptr<World> object. Alternatively, we could always return a World object, and throw an exception when the user gives bad input (instead of returning a nullptr), but the fact that a function might throw an exception can’t be expressed through its function signature, so I don’t favor that option (plus there are some potential performance concerns).

std::optional<World> is really be the best fit here (at least in my opinion), because it will give us the best of:

  1. Explicitly expressing intent + behavior
  2. Good performance
  3. Meaningful life-cycle management

I just don’t have C++17 right now, and I can’t risk upgrading to Bionic until July 16, because I have a live demo scheduled for the 13th.

content.raw: ok
content.html: ok

content.raw:
As for `const`, I have some mixed feelings. Technically we can, because there wouldn’t be a violation of “physical” constness, but I think there might be a violation of “logical” constness. It really depends on the exact relationship between a “World” and its “Engine”. Those relationships could even vary between different physics engines or different features within physics engines.

I think for now the safest thing to do is have const-qualified and const-unqualified versions of every function that returns any kind of Entity. That way, we never risk an Entity breaking the logical constness of its parent.
content.html:
As for const, I have some mixed feelings. Technically we can, because there wouldn’t be a violation of “physical” constness, but I think there might be a violation of “logical” constness. It really depends on the exact relationship between a “World” and its “Engine”. Those relationships could even vary between different physics engines or different features within physics engines.

I think for now the safest thing to do is have const-qualified and const-unqualified versions of every function that returns any kind of Entity. That way, we never risk an Entity breaking the logical constness of its parent.

content.raw: sounds good
content.html: sounds good

content.raw: the `std::size_t` parameters in these functions could all be `const` right?
content.html: the std::size_t parameters in these functions could all be const right?

content.raw:
Adding a `const` to a value parameter of a function declaration doesn’t have any effect on the function’s signature. Classes that override this function can choose to add or remove the const, and there’s nothing we can do about it.

The recommended practice from Clang and MSVC compiler developers is to leave off the const on value parameters in function declarations \(because it adds “noise” to your declaration without having literally any effect\), but do include the const in the function definition whenever it’s desired.
content.html:
Adding a const to a value parameter of a function declaration doesn’t have any effect on the function’s signature. Classes that override this function can choose to add or remove the const, and there’s nothing we can do about it.

The recommended practice from Clang and MSVC compiler developers is to leave off the const on value parameters in function declarations (because it adds “noise” to your declaration without having literally any effect), but do include the const in the function definition whenever it’s desired.

content.raw: if the underlying physics engine doesn't have a method for computing the aggregate `ModelCenterOfMass`, we could compute it by aggregating the link center-of-masses (pretty easily with the `ignition::math::Inertial` class)
content.html: if the underlying physics engine doesn't have a method for computing the aggregate ModelCenterOfMass, we could compute it by aggregating the link center-of-masses (pretty easily with the ignition::math::Inertial class)

content.raw:
Right, I expect that we’ll have a lot of pre-made feature implementations, where if a plugin provides features A and B, then it can inherit an implementation class to also get feature C for free. But if a plugin can implement feature C more efficiently than our pre-made approach \(for example, a physics engine might cache each model’s CoM calculation\), then it can use its internal implementation instead of our pre-made one.

Or if we want to get really fancy, we can make it so that when a user requests a feature from a plugin, then it will use that plugin’s implementation, but if the plugin doesn’t offer the implementation, then we’ll use the fallback implementation if the plugin provides the features required by the fallback.
content.html:
Right, I expect that we’ll have a lot of pre-made feature implementations, where if a plugin provides features A and B, then it can inherit an implementation class to also get feature C for free. But if a plugin can implement feature C more efficiently than our pre-made approach (for example, a physics engine might cache each model’s CoM calculation), then it can use its internal implementation instead of our pre-made one.

Or if we want to get really fancy, we can make it so that when a user requests a feature from a plugin, then it will use that plugin’s implementation, but if the plugin doesn’t offer the implementation, then we’ll use the fallback implementation if the plugin provides the features required by the fallback.

content.raw:
So far I've mainly been thinking about this feature system from the perspective of the interface for physics plugin providers, and this does a great job with that interface.

As I think about it from the other side of the interface, such a user of `ign-gazebo` who wants to load a xml model / world file and then call ign-physics, I'm wondering how much knowledge `ign-gazebo` is required to have about all these features. Would a world file be able to list required features in text format? Currently, FeatureLists just supports symbols as a template parameter.
content.html:
So far I've mainly been thinking about this feature system from the perspective of the interface for physics plugin providers, and this does a great job with that interface.

As I think about it from the other side of the interface, such a user of ign-gazebo who wants to load a xml model / world file and then call ign-physics, I'm wondering how much knowledge ign-gazebo is required to have about all these features. Would a world file be able to list required features in text format? Currently, FeatureLists just supports symbols as a template parameter.

content.raw:
Right, I think the design doc touches on this a bit, but here’s the brief overview:

1. We'll pre-define some standard feature sets. When a user loads a plugin that uses one of these standard feature sets, we'll be able to detect it using `plugin->QueryInterface<T>()` and then pass the plugin an object which expresses that standard set of features.
2. Users who want a custom set of features will need to have their plugin accept a generic object that doesn't express any features, and then we'll provide some "dynamic casting" tools \(similar to `RequestFeatures` which has already been implemented\) to convert the generic object into an object that expresses the custom features that the user’s plugin requires. If that “dynamic cast” fails, then it falls on the user’s plugin to decide how to proceed.

In both cases, we don’t need the SDF to tell us what features are required, because in case \(1\) we can detect it from the interfaces provided by the plugin, and in case \(2\) we rely on the user’s plugin to extract the features that it needs.

`ign-gazebo` shouldn't need any knowledge about physics features, because that will all be handled within `ign-physics` and `ign-plugin`.
content.html:
Right, I think the design doc touches on this a bit, but here’s the brief overview:

  1. We'll pre-define some standard feature sets. When a user loads a plugin that uses one of these standard feature sets, we'll be able to detect it using plugin->QueryInterface<T>() and then pass the plugin an object which expresses that standard set of features.
  2. Users who want a custom set of features will need to have their plugin accept a generic object that doesn't express any features, and then we'll provide some "dynamic casting" tools (similar to RequestFeatures which has already been implemented) to convert the generic object into an object that expresses the custom features that the user’s plugin requires. If that “dynamic cast” fails, then it falls on the user’s plugin to decide how to proceed.

In both cases, we don’t need the SDF to tell us what features are required, because in case (1) we can detect it from the interfaces provided by the plugin, and in case (2) we rely on the user’s plugin to extract the features that it needs.

ign-gazebo shouldn't need any knowledge about physics features, because that will all be handled within ign-physics and ign-plugin.
